Core inflation YoY is around 0.2%. It's better for the FED to react to inflation when it is closer to it's target than try to stoke it before it has even taken off. The argument about them losing credibility if they don't raise is weak, given they are the 'boss' of the rate; they can do whatever they want. Raising rates now will hurt more people than it will benefit; the FED will only be giving large corporations an excuse to lay-off people to reduce costs, as their costs would have gone up from debt financing and those with surplus cash will benefit.

Not changing forecast but adding commentary:  The issue is the credit markets not the stock market.  Liquidity has all but disappeared in the junk bond market spiking interest rates and widening the spread as capital flees to treasuries (safety).  So the Fed has forces pushing itself in both directions - (1) not to raise since there's market turmoil and (2) to raise since the pension funds are even in more of a bind with lowering yields.

I’m debating between what the fed “ought to” do and probability of what they “will do”. In the past the two were the same most of the time, but this time around it doesn’t seem that clear. I believe that the Fed should wait till next year as the economy is reaching a point where most metrics are only now turning “green” and there does not seem to be any significant threat of inflation. Also, the impact of a rate hike has the potential to jolt emerging markets significantly, considering China has already seen significant capital outflows. However Yellen’s statements seem to hint more strongly towards a December hike. To a lesser extent I think President Obama would also like to start his last year in office and say something positive about the economy at the state of the union on Jan 16th with the first rate hike behind him.
Hence I’m changing my forecast from 45% to 60%.

The timing of the initial interest rate move is less important than that of the second.  The second rate hike sets the path of the tightening cycle, which will affect the path of currencies, stocks and bonds.  If the Fed raises once but then returns to its Hamlet routine, we will see similar market uncertainty as we have had over the past year, with the only difference being 25 lousy basis points.  A second rate hike, however, enables economists to employ their handy forecasting tool -- a ruler that connects the two points and then extends the trend into the future.

Regarding today's "emergency meeting". This is nothing out of the ordinary. This happens every few months & there is nothing "emergency" about it, despite what external bloggers may report. More detail: The Fed is holding a regular meeting of the board of governors to discuss the primary credit discount rate on Monday. It's the rate charged to commercial banks and other depository institutions on loans they receive from their regional Federal Reserve Bank's lending facility - the discount window - and has been at 75 bps for the primary credit program since February 2010. At the last such meeting, 5 of the 12 regional Fed banks called for a hike to said rate. However, these recommendations require support from the Board of Governors. It is highly unlikely that the Board (Yellen, Fischer, Tarullo, Powell & Brainard) will approve a discount rate move outside of a move in the fed funds target. Nothing to be concerned about & zero chance of a change today with a decision still "technically" up in the air for Dec.

I've forecasted this question a couple of times, and have recently come to the following conclusions.  First, the data today is not materially different from the data available in July/August.  Second, the Fed has information that I don't have access to, so, whatever way I rationalize my forecast, it's just a guess made on data I don't have.  The Fed has two explicit mandates: defence of the US currency and full employment.  It seems it also has an implicit goal: to temper the natural business cycle.  So, if the data doesn't make much difference, then what is the real question?  Will Janet Yellen have the courage to raise rates?  She may be swayed by arguments made by other members of the FOMC, but it's her decision in the end.  I am leaning against an increase for using the following rationalizations:

Recent comments from Janet Yellon indicate obliquely that she will. It is a political decision, not an economic one, so it increases and decreases with headlines, including of H. Clinton's popularity. I believe it will be Obama's decision, how communicated is uncertain.

In this essay, Wm Cohan represents the pov of the guys who want a rate hike. Bernanke defends seven years of low rates with arguments that still apply now. 
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/12/business/dealbook/a-debate-with-bernanke-over-the-feds-easy-money-policies.html
The numbers don't support hiking rates even now. Statements like "a quarter point won't hurt" sound like the addict's "I've been good so long; just a taste won't hurt." Also, there is a hysteresis effect involved here: the damage done by raising rates too soon is harder to correct than the damage done by raising rates too late. The members of the Fed are well aware of that. If the Fed does hike rates now, it will be for political reasons, not economic ones, and the political pressure is to raise rates. Is there a political downside to keeping rates low? As Larry Wilmore repeatedly points out, "Obama don't care;" i.e., political consequences aren't important to the administration anymore. So that's a point against rate hikes. The Federal Open Market Committee operates by consensus rather than vote tally, a process that generally tends to insulate individuals in a group from retaliation. That's another point against rate hikes. My forecast is really my guess at the probability the FOMC will reach a politically motivated consensus to raise rates in the next six weeks.

It seems like the strong jobs report has the FED considering it, however there are so many other factors in play. CPI is low (near 0 for the year) and without a threat of inflation it is hard to justify a rate increase on the news that wages have made a small uptick recently.  I don't see why it seems an obvious decision to  hike rates when it appears quantitive easing may finally be helping to raise  stagnate wages for the lower and middle class workers. Several economist have pointed this out such as Paul Krugman. There is no data that I've seen that would appear to show that high inflation is a growing concern especially with such low energy prices. It would seem more prudent to wait for wages to increase to the point where a healthy moderate inflation became apparent then slowly raise rates. However, if there is another strong jobs report and any increase in energy cost I could see the Federal Reserve making a small incremental move. For one thing, having rates at near 0 takes an important tool away from the FED. If there is any hiccups in a sensitive economy and rates are at zero, the FED will simply have little they can do, even if it just a psychological effect on the market if they simply can't reduce rates lower then where they stand. This could be a small added incentive to increase rates while things are relatively stable. I think the December numbers will be critical in the final decision. Despite the recent polls of economist predicting an increase I'm more skeptical. I cant see them taking a risk of dampening the small recent growth in wages with near 0 inflation in 2015. If even a small increase has a negative effect on this growth, they will be unlikely to reduce the rates once an increase is implemented. There is also the international pressures to keep rates low. Even as the US economy seems to mildly strengthening, the global economy is fragile. An increased rate may hinder international trade and specifically hurt developing countries purchasing power. Considering the interlinked global economy and the chance that a global slowdown could trickle back into the US economy,  it would seem wiser to wait until an increase is more obviously needed then it is now. This one is close to 43% yes right for me right now with a possibility of an increase if December shows further economic progress both globally and domestically.

However, if there is another strong jobs report and any increase in energy cost I could see the Federal Reserve making a small incremental move. For one thing, having rates at near 0 takes an important tool away from the FED. If there is any hiccups in a sensitive economy and rates are at zero, the FED will simply have little they can do, even if it just a psychological effect on the market if they simply can't reduce rates lower then where they stand. This could be a small added incentive to increase rates while things are relatively stable. I think the December numbers will be critical in the final decision. Despite the recent polls of economist predicting an increase I'm more skeptical. I cant see them taking a risk of dampening the small recent growth in wages with near 0 inflation in 2015. If even a small increase has a negative effect on this growth, they will be unlikely to reduce the rates once an increase is implemented. There is also the international pressures to keep rates low. Even as the US economy seems to mildly strengthening, the global economy is fragile. An increased rate may hinder international trade and specifically hurt developing countries purchasing power. Considering the interlinked global economy and the chance that a global slowdown could trickle back into the US economy,  it would seem wiser to wait until an increase is more obviously needed then it is now. This one is close to 43% yes right for me right now with a possibility of an increase if December shows further economic progress both globally and domestically.

I vote yes. I think the fed is coming around to the realization that ultra low interest rates are having a litany of unintended affects on the US economy. Namely, that most large public companies are taking on huge debts cheaply (low interest rates plus tax write offs for debt) for the sole purpose of share buybacks and dividends. The intention of cheap capital was for companies to invest capital in infastructure and R&D. I can't really name a fortuane 500 company that took advantage of that. Low interest rates are not accomplishing their intended purpose so why keep them around? This combined with comparatively inspiring job and wage growth should be enough to convinve the fed to take the bold step of 0.25%

Today's Financial Times reports collapsing US job growth.  In the Front page article, "US job surge paves way for rate rise", the author eventually gets around to pointing out (in the last paragraph) that the 210,000 per month average for the first half of 2015, has fallen to an average of 187,000 per month over the last 3 months, a decline of over 10%.  This, along with GDP expectations falling to 1.5%, low inflation, stagnating export growth, the damage higher rates would do by: slowing the economy, strengthening the dollar, thereby weakening exports, reducing inflation by lowering the price of imports, argue for no rate hike.  FED has accomplished their mission of changing rate expectations.

An interest rate increase is on the near horizon but most likely not by the end of the year. The rate increase will likely happen in March/April of 2016. The October jobs report and unemployment rate are great but the Fed will likely want to see this sustained a bit longer and the end of the year reports are a bit skewed because of seasonal employment, etc. If numbers remain good over the 1st quarter of the new year than the rate increase will probably happen.

The latest jobs report provides the ammunition that the FOMC majority has been seeking to justify a rate increase. Plainly they have wanted to do this for some time but up until now its been equally plain that such a move would be too easily assailed as stupid for them to act. I still believe that raising rates is premature-no signs of wage inflation and labor force participation is too low. Also, the international situation is at best fragile. So the most likely scenario is that any rate increase in December will have to be reversed next year, blowing up any pretense the Fed has to being able to provide forward guidance. But the malign influence of Fischer  (and Akerlof, Yellen's sort of better half who  shares Shiller's belief about the bubble risks of an  ultra low interest rate environment), will likely carry the day.

There is no rationale to raise rates in the current environment. Employment growth has slowed and inflation data has weakened. Moreover, wages have been barely creeping above inflation and for the most part have been stagnant. If the Fed raises rates now, then they will suffer from the same fate as the Euro central bank did when it had to reverse course after they raised rates when oil went up and was reflected in the overall inflation data. From Forbes contributor Oliver Pursche:
"I have long considered a December rate hike unlikely. The Fed’s next meeting coincides with what is historically a thin period of trading. Investors are out on holiday, there tend to be fewer news events to trade off, and in general there’s less liquidity floating around. Raising rates in that kind of environment would amplify volatility unnecessarily, and if the Fed can avoid turbulence by waiting, it probably will.
While some of the factors that made a December hike unlikely have diminished–specifically, government risk related to budgetary brinksmanship in the legislative branch–I still think December is unlikely given continued concerns over global growth and the drop we’ve seen in third-quarter profits. Moreover, if October employment figures (set to be released on Nov. 6) come in weak, there is no justification for raising rates."

Probably not.  Betting that the FED would raise rates has been a losing proposition in recent times.  Today, the FED has two imperatives:  (1) defend the currency and control inflation/deflation, and (2) encourage full employment and economic vigor.  The FED is less independent than it once was, and day-to-day politics have more of an impact on its decisions.   At every turn, the FED has found reasons not to act.   Most of the discussion involves questions about what constitutes full employment.  But other new reasons come along all the time, including recently announced monetary easing decisions in Europe and China.  Bear in mind that the FED also has an unstated third imperative no one likes to talk about.  One of the biggest beneficiaries of zero rates is the U.S. government itself.  Given the debt burden, keeping FED funds at zero has significant budgetary implications.  One day, the FED will act to raise short term rates, but when the vote comes in December, the easiest pathway will be to vote no once again.

The economy is still weak, and the Fed is learning that interest rates can be somewhat controlled even at the zero lower bound. On the other hand, problems in China  and other developing countries could force these countries to a sell-off of US treasuries at a greater rate. This would incentivize the Federal Reserve to keep the rates low at least until next year when they are more certain (hopefully) that developing nations are not going to have a demand shock. On the other hand, the current success with interest rates at the zero lower bound does not last, they may be forced to raise rates. Also, if the banks are unwilling to cooperate with such low interest rates treasuries being forced onto them, the private side of the Federal Reserve would try to steer monetary policy towards higher rates. If bankers are squeezed, which is unlikely, they may not be able to handle such low rates. The most important factor, however, is the stick market from now until December 31st. If the stock market does very well, the Fed may think it can raise rates again. On the other hand, this may also signal a bubble which is not a sign of real growth. Depending on where we actually are in the business cycle (which is hard to determine itself) there may be real reason to raise rates in November/December. I think the Fed will play cautiously, however, and enjoy their newly-discovered powers at the zero lower bound until at least early 2016.

There is a lot of political pressure to raise rates, but inflation simply isn't present. Using a "pre-emptive strike" for raising rates just doesn't make academic sense to me. I agree there is a lot of political pressure to raise rates and general concern in the marketplace about leaving rates at zero for so many years, but I fail to see the academic argument supporting an immediate rate rise and I think the folks at the Fed will ultimately agree. The argument has gone from an academic one to a psychological one - "raise rates now to get the wait over with." I don't think this holds academic mustard. The Fed is independent enough to make the correct economic decision regardless of the political noise surrounding the Fed's decision to keep rates so low for so long. If inflation appears the Fed can always quickly adjust up rates if need be at subsequent meetings.

The consensus among the majority of economists is that it will be important for the Fed to begin to recoup the use of its most effective tool (until the advent of quantitative easing) which has been the Fed Funds rate.  This has been extensively reported since the end of QE3 (or was that 4?). Looking at market projections of a 3-3.5% rate expectation in the coming year (Bloomberg) and the reaction by the markets to the results of the most recent Fed meeting demonstrates that the markets want an increase in the base rate (a rate increase would be perceived as a vote of confidence in the domestic economy and an acknowledgement that the issues in China and the weaker Euro markets may not have as large a domestic impact as initially thought).  Couple her remarks with the news today that GDP rose more than previously estimated for the second quarter (3.9% vs 3.7%, median expectations were at 3.7%).  Growth in the second quarter was fueled by increased consumer and investment in commercial and residential construction, both segments of the economy that generally leverage broad based growth throughout the economy.  Her remarks yesterday pretty well seal the deal as I see it.

The Fed has been announcing that an increase in the US federal funds rate would occur this year since January and, even though inflation remains low, Yellen doesn't want the Fed to lose its credibility by not hiking rates when it said it was going to. Long term, keeping the institution's credibility intact is more important to the US economy than what it does or does not do with interest rates at this juncture. Plus, with consistently strong monthly job gains, the unemployment rate is just over 5% and Janet Yellen is reportedly watching this indicator more closely than any other, and the funds rate will likely be increased just fractions of a percentage point, too little to sway the economy in any significant way.

The case for an increase is due to solid job gains, lower unemployment rate and a rebound in wages in July/Aug. In addition, economic growth accelerated in the second quarter after bad weather constrained it at the start of the year.

The Fed has held off on rate increases even as unemployment numbers have dropped below their stated threshold. The US is a relatively bright spot in the global economy, but there is still significant structural weakness which makes a rate hike risky.

Fed wants to raise, and has signaled a raise, for a long time. They keep hoping the data will support this decision, but it hasn't yet. Almost all economic reasons to raise rates involve inflation somehow. Inflation isn't at it's 2% target, and leading indicators aren't signalling that it will get there anytime soon: dollar up; commodities down; wages growing but not spectacularly; deflation present in many places globally. If there start to be signs that inflation is moving up in any meaningful way, I'll raise my prediction to the 75-80% range. If China crashes hard or some other economic bogeyman pops up (Greek elections, anyone?), I'll lower it to perhaps <50%.

http://www.wsj.com/articles/san-francisco-feds-williams-sees-rate-increase-this-year-if-risks-dissipate-1441658566
"For much of 2015, John Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, has projected a rosy U.S. economic outlook, seeing solid output growth, steady unemployment declines and an approaching need to increase short-term interest rates.
Now, as the Fed weighs whether to raise rates at its policy meeting next week, the optimistic economist has many caveats.
...
In June, Mr. Williams projected two interest-rate increases this year. These days he hedges on whether the Fed will act even once. It depends, he said, on how the central bank assesses the new risks that have materialized in the past few months. If the risks don’t appear to be seriously threatening, then he could see “interest-rate increases some time later this year, or an interest-rate increase.”
...
However, he’s concerned about headwinds to the outlook. The change in financial conditions since the July Fed meeting, in the form of falling stock prices and a rising dollar, “have been pretty big,” he said. “It’s not the case that nothing has changed since our last [policy] meeting.”
